Yahoo mangles links that I type in sometimes..it's not your computer.
You have to copy that whole thing as a string on one line instead of 
pressing on it.  Here is an alternate route to the paper (let's hope 
this one works):

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?bruce:gecco01

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> 
> 
> Well, yes, I suppose I agree, but that wasn't my focus. I'm curious
> about how to 
> get a confidence output from a system. I think any system should be
> decomposed, 
> but how? There are many methods that do many things, some better 
than
> others.
> I haven't read anything before on decision confidence, and I 
couldn't
> follow 
> the link Ken gave. This computer isn't so reliable ( corrupt 
version of
> win98 ver1 ), 
> so I'll have to wait till I get back up to campus to read what he
> posted. 
> As a matter of fact, I'm still learning about the vast number of
> different network flavors 
> invented so far. Once the papers about how slow back propagation is
> started coming 
> out, the variety of learning algorithms exploded. 
> When I get a better handle on it, I think the NEAT algorithm would 
blend
> well with many 
> of the structures I've been seeing. The LSTM neuron is pretty 
novel and
> has good learning 
> characteristics. It could become a subset of the NEAT tool set. 
There is
> nothing wrong 
> with evolving networks that learn things as they go. The challenge 
is
> evaluation fitness. 
> The solution space may well explode when you start adding 
variables like
> that, but 
> then that's the biggest strength of the genetic algorithm. I've 
had too
> much coffee, I could 
> babble for hours... Sorry for the ramble. 
> 
> Chad 
> 
> 
> > 
> Hi Chad, 
> 
> Yes I think I understand. I would tend to think of the technique 
you 
> describe as being a further level of task decomposition. I 
described 
> braking the goal task into layers, high to low. I think the 
technique 
> you describe would fit in nicely by taking a sub-task at a 
specific 
> layer and braking it down further. Would you agree? 
> 
> Colin.
